FRS_Method: GPS CARRIER PHASE STATIC RELATIVE POSITION

_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: Expansion or Renovation of Facility or Stystems. Installed a new Booster Compressor, High Stage Compressor, Intercooler Package, and Blast Tunnel Freezer Evaporators.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Lakeside Foods, INC.

500 INDUSTRIAL PARK ROAD

P.O. BOX 430

BROOTEN, MN  56316-0430



1.    Facility Policy



Lakeside Foods, Inc. is committed to the prevention of any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.  If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the local fire department and other authorities to mitigate any release and its impact on employees, the public and the environment.  Lakeside Foods is complying with OSHAA?s Process Safety Management Standard, 29 CFR 1910.119 and EPAA?s Risk Management Program regulations. 40 CFR Part 68 to deal with the risks involved with the storage, handling and processing of hazardous chemicals.



2.    Facility Process



The primary activity at the facility is the processing of peas and sweet corn into a frozen state.  Anhydrous ammonia is used as a refrigerant in the processing of the vegetables.



3.    The Accidental Release Prevention Program



The facility has implemented standards of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration,(OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, A?Storage and Handling of Anhydrous AmmoniaA? and the OSHA Process Safety Management standard, 29 CFR 1910.119.  Important elements of our prevention program are Employee Participation; Process Safety Information; Process Hazard Analysis; Standard Operating Procedures; Training; Contractor Safety Compliance; Pre-startup Safety Review; Mechanical Integrity Audits; Hot Work Permit System; Management of Change; Incident Investigation; Emergency Response Plan; Compliance Audits.



4.    The Five Year Accident History



EPA's RMP regulation defines "accident" as the following: 



"The release must be from a covered process and involve a regulated substance held above its threshold quantity in the process. The release must have caused at least one of the following: 



?    On-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage (?68.42(a)); or

?    Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or shelterin

g in place (?68.42(a))." 



Based on the above definition and an investigation into the facility's accident history conducted during the Process Hazard Analysis study on June 19-20, 2018 there have been no releases of ammonia that meet this criteria in the past five years (June 2013 through June 2018). In addition, there have been no injuries resulting from an ammonia release, nor any releases or "near misses" that warranted an internal incident investigation.





5.    The Emergency Response Program



The facility has:



A.    A written Emergency Action Plan in accordance with OSHA Standard 29 CFR 1910.38.



B.    Provided State and Local authorities with the Emergency Planning and Community Right-To-Know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA).



C.    A written Emergency Response Program in accordance with OSHA 29 CFR 1910.120 (HAZWOPER), including pre-emergency planning and employee training.



6.    Planned Change to Improve Safety



Safety improvement is a continuous process at the facility.  Evaluations and audits are performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions in the facility.
